    Medicinal Chemistry Strategies for the Development of Kinase Inhibitors Targeting Point Mutations

    • Xiaoyun Lu*
      Xiaoyun Lu
      International Cooperative Laboratory of Traditional Chinese Medicine Modernization and Innovative Drug Discovery of Chinese Ministry of Education (MOE), Guangzhou City Key Laboratory of Precision Chemical Drug Development, School of Pharmacy, Jinan University, 601 Huangpu Avenue West, Guangzhou 510632, China
      *X.L.: email, [email protected]; phone, +86-20-85223259
      More by Xiaoyun Lu
      View Biography
      http://orcid.org/0000-0001-7931-6873
      • , 
    • Jeff B. Smaill
      Jeff B. Smaill
      Auckland Cancer Society Research Centre, School of Medical Sciences, The University of Auckland, Private Bag 92019, Auckland 1142, New Zealand
      More by Jeff B. Smaill
      View Biography
      • , and 
    • Ke Ding*
      Ke Ding

      More by Ke Ding
      View Biography
      http://orcid.org/0000-0001-9016-812X
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2020, 63, 19, 10726–10741

    SUBJECTS:
    • Cancer,
    • Drug resistance,

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Clinically acquired resistance to small molecule kinase inhibitors (SMKIs) has become a major “unmet clinical need” in cancer therapy. To date, there are six SMKIs to be approved for the treatment of cancer patients through targeting of clinically acquired resistance caused by on-target mutations. These are mainly focused on the mutant kinases Bcr-Abl T315I, EGFR T790M, and ALK L1196M. Herein, we summarize the major medicinal chemistry strategies employed in the discovery of these representative SMKIs, such as avoiding steric hindrance, making additional interactions with mutated residues, and forming a covalent bond with an active site cysteine to override resistance observed for reversible inhibitors. Additionally, we also briefly describe allosteric kinase inhibitors and proteolysis targeting chimera (PROTAC) as two other potential strategies while addressing future opportunities in this area.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Protein kinases (simply referred to herein as kinases) are enzymes that transfer the terminal phosphate group of ATP to tyrosine, threonine, or serine residues of proteins. Such protein phosphorylation drives signal transduction in cells regulating a series of biological process, such as cell growth, differentiation, metastasis, homeostasis, and death.(1,2) Kinases have been intensively investigated as a major class of targets for drug discovery, accounting for 25–30% of all targets screened in the pharmaceutical industry. Since 2001, the FDA has approved 59 small molecule kinase inhibitors (SMKIs) leading to the emergence of the field of targeted drug therapy for cancer and other diseases (Figure 1 and Table S1),(3,4) resulting in greatly improved clinical outcomes for patients. Despite these encouraging clinical benefits, SMKIs are still faced with two critical challenges in both the clinical and experimental oncology settings.(5) First, type I and type II SMKIs bind at the conserved ATP-binding pocket of the target kinase and therefore lack selectivity against other targets in the human kinome. Second, clinically acquired resistance to SMKIs generally occurs after 1–2 years of clinical use driven by secondary or tertiary kinase mutations (on-target mutations) or kinase bypass signaling (off-target resistance). This second phenomenon has become one of the most serious problems in cancer therapy.(6,7) Kinase on-target mutations have been found to most frequently occur at the so-called oncogene “gatekeeper” residue (e.g., Bcr-Abl T315I, EGFR T790M, and ALK L1196M mutations), a covalent binding site that drives inhibitor potency (e.g., EGFR C797S and BTK C481S mutations), and at residues on the “solvent-front” (e.g., ALK G1202R and ROS G2032R mutations). Among secondary mutations, the gatekeeper mutation is the most common, typically resulting in resistance by sterically impeding the binding of SMKIs. The challenges derived from on-target mutations have prompted medicinal chemists to design new generations of SMKIs that can override treatment-related drug resistance observed for existing agents.
    An analysis of the FDA-approved SMKIs indicates that there are currently six examples registered for the treatment of cancer that target clinically acquired resistance caused by kinase point mutations (Figure 1, colored orange). Ponatinib, first approved in 2012, has been shown to overcome clinically acquired resistance in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) patients treated with imatinib induced by the Bcr-Abl T315I gatekeeper mutation.(8) Ceritinib was approved in 2014 as a second-generation ALK inhibitor for the treatment of non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients who have developed acquired resistance to crizotinib through a number of resistance mutations, especially the ALK L1196M gatekeeper mutation. However, ceritinib does not overcome the ALK G1202R mutation, another common crizotinib resistance mutation observed in patients.(9) Lorlatinib, a macrocyclic third-generation ALK inhibitor, was discovered to overcome the ALK G1202R mutation and similarly positioned ROS1 G2032R resistance mutation detected in NSCLC patients treated with crizotinib, resulting in FDA approval in 2018.(10) Osimertinib, approved in 2015, is a third-generation wild type EGFR-sparing irreversible inhibitor of mutant forms of EGFR that overcomes acquired resistance observed in NSCLC patients caused by the EGFR T790M gatekeeper mutation.(11) However, in EGFR-mutant NSCLC and BTK-mutant chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), no drugs have been marketed for the treatment of osimertinib-resistant EGFR T790M/C797S mutations and ibrutinib-resistant BTK C481S mutation. Indeed, acquired drug resistance to SMKIs caused by on-target mutations like these is a very common paradigm and remains a major clinical challenge in cancer therapy.
    The main mechanisms by which point mutations lead to drug resistance include (i) causing steric hindrance or electrical mismatch to decrease drug binding capability, (ii) increasing affinity of ATP for the ATP-binding domain, making it harder for the drug to compete for active site occupancy, (iii) disturbing a covalent bond formed between the inhibitor and the active site of the protein. In this review we summarized the major medicinal chemistry strategies for discovery of representative SMKIs which can overcome on-target point mutations that drive acquired resistance. Herein, we focus mainly on the successful clinically approved drugs that have addressed acquired resistance through optimization of existing drug classes using ingenious strategies including avoiding steric hindrance with mutated residues, making interactions with mutated residues, and forming covalent bonds with active site cysteines to override resistance observed for reversible inhibitor counterparts. Additionally, we also briefly describe allosteric kinase inhibitors and proteolysis targeting chimera (PROTAC) as two other potential strategies while addressing future opportunities in this area.

    2. Medicinal Chemistry Strategies

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    2.1. Avoiding Steric Hindrance with the Mutated Residue

    2.1.1. Abl T315I

    The Bcr-Abl fusion oncogene is constitutively active and crucial for malignant transformation in CML.(12,13) Abl tyrosine kinase inhibitors were subsequently developed as effective therapy for CML. Imatinib (1, Figure 2) was the first approved SMKI for the treatment of CML,(14,15) pioneering the era of targeted drug therapy in oncology. However, emerging acquired resistance to imatinib has become a major challenge in the clinic. It has been observed that the occurrence of point mutations in the kinase domain of Abl is the primary mechanism for clinical resistance to imatinib.(16,17) Over 50 different Bcr-Abl point mutations have been reported from the genetic sequencing of clinical samples, among which the most common T315I gatekeeper mutation accounts for 15–20% of all acquired resistance.(18,19) In this mutation, threonine is replaced by the larger and more lipophilic isoleucine residue. A protein X-ray crystal structure indicates that the T315I mutation leads to the loss of a fundamental hydrogen bond with the aminopyrimidine hinge-binding scaffold of imatinib and a steric clash with the imatinib methyl-substituted phenyl ring, diminishing the inhibitory potency of imatinib against this mutant variant (Figure 2).(18,20) Unfortunately, the second generation of approved Bcr-Abl inhibitors, dasatinib, nilotinib and bosutinib, suffer from the same liability, having been found to be incapable of inhibiting the T315I gatekeeper mutation due to similar steric hindrance.(19,21)
    Ponatinib (2, Figure 2), a third-generation Bcr-Abl inhibitor approved in 2012, was developed to overcome Bcr-Abl T315I resistance by using an alkyne linker connected to an imidazo[1,2-b]pyridazine core.(22) The detailed optimization process to develop this agent has been reviewed by our group.(23) Ponatinib exhibits excellent potency against the Bcr-Abl wild type kinase (IC50 = 0.37 nM) and the T315I mutant (IC50 = 2 nM), as well as other clinically relevant mutants in the Bcr-Abl kinase domain (IC50 = 0.30–0.44 nM).(8) The key factor contributing to the high T315I mutant potency of ponatinib is the ability of the alkyne to avoid steric clash with Ile315 while maintaining the crucial remaining interactions with the Abl kinase domain.(22) But it is also suggested that the small volume of alkyne leads to the kinase selectivity of ponatinib (selectivity entropy Ssel = 4) far worse than that of imatinib (Ssel = 0.8) in a panel of more than 300 kinase activity assays.(24) To date, ponatinib is the only approved drug for the treatment of CML patients harboring a Bcr-Abl T315I mutation, although it was temporarily suspended in 2013 with noted occurrence of cardiovascular thrombotic side effects.(25)

    2.1.2. ALK L1196M or G1202R

    Anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) has been identified as a validated target in oncology drug development after the discovery that two main fusion genes encoding the proteins EML4-ALK and NPM-ALK result in constitutively active ALK kinase activity driving oncogenic signaling in NSCLC and anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL), respectively.(26,27) Significant efforts have been made over the past two decades to develop ALK inhibitors for the treatment of cancer. Crizotinib (3, Figure 3), a first-generation ALK, c-Met, and ROS1 inhibitor developed by Pfizer,(28) gained FDA approval for the treatment of ALK-positive and ROS1-positive NSCLC in 2011 and 2016, respectively, bringing significant clinical benefit to patients.(29,30) Like imatinib, acquired resistance mediated by on-target mutations inevitably emerged during the clinical use of crizotinib. For ALK, the most frequent mutations appear at the gatekeeper L1196M, the solvent-front G1202R, the regulatory αC helix C1156Y and around the DFG motif G1269A.(31,9) Second- and third-generation ALK inhibitors have been developed to overcome these resistance mutations.(32,33) Among them, ceritinib, alectinib, brigatinib, and lorlatinib have been successively approved by the FDA for the treatment of metastatic NSCLC harboring mutant forms of ALK (Figure 1). The second-generation inhibitors ceritinib and alectinib effectively inhibit the majority of crizotinib-resistant mutations, especially the gatekeeper ALK L1196M mutation. The strategies used to optimize these second-generation ALK inhibitors will be described in further detail below. However, it has been demonstrated that they unfortunately cannot overcome the clinically important crizotinib-resistant G1202R solvent-front mutation.(9,34)
    In the ALK gatekeeper L1196M mutation, leucine is replaced by the more polar and sterically hindered methionine residue, leading to a loss of nonpolar van der Vaals interactions between the methyl substituent of crizotinib and the leucine residue while introducing a steric clash that interferes with crizotinib binding.(31,35) The solvent-front G1202R mutation also causes a steric clash with the piperidine ring of crizotinib due to the increased bulk of the arginine residue of the mutant. In 2018, a third-generation macrocyclic ALK inhibitor, lorlatinib (4, Figure 3), was approved for the treatment of ALK-positive metastatic NSCLC resistant to crizotinib, ceritinib, and alectinib.(36,37) Lorlatinib was designed with a rigid amide-linked 12-membered macrocycle instead of the more linear crizotinib scaffold. It is a structural modification that eliminates steric hindrance with Met1196 and Arg1202 (Figure 3).(38,32) As expected, lorlatinib displays superior potency against all known clinically acquired ALK mutations, including the G1202R mutation, demonstrating an antiproliferative IC50 of 77 nM against Ba/F3 cells expressing ALK G1202R. Moreover, lorlatinib shows excellent kinase selectivity and remarkable activity against ROS1 and the clinically acquired resistance mutations ROS1 G2032R and ROS1 L2026M.(10) Of note, lorlatinib has good blood–brain barrier (BBB) penetration and central nerve system (CNS) exposure leading to its use as an effective agent against neuroblastoma and metastatic brain cancer.(38) An X-ray crystal structure of lorlatinib with ALK demonstrates that it forms two fundamental hydrogen bonds with Glu1197 and Met1199 and that the constrained macrocycle fits well in the ATP-binding site without any steric clashes (Figure 3).

    2.1.3. TRKA G595R or G677C

    Tropomyosin receptor kinases (TRKA, TRKB, and TRKC), activated by the neurotrophin family of growth factors, have been identified as effective therapeutic targets for a diverse but rare set of cancers harboring NTRK fusions or rearrangements.(39,40) Numerous TRK inhibitors have been developed,(41) with larotrectinib (5 [LOXO-101], Figure 4) in particular being notable as the first SMKI to gain approval in a “tissue-agnostic” setting in 2018 (i.e., approval for the treatment of multiple different cancer indications that contain NTRK fusions).(42) In 2019, another multikinase inhibitor, entrectinib, also gained FDA approval for the treatment of ROS1-positive metastatic NSCLC and NTRK gene fusion-positive solid tumors.(43,44)
    Although the first-generation TRK inhibitors exhibit profound efficacy, acquired resistance invariably develops due to secondary mutations in the TRK kinase domain.(45) Like ALK and ROS1, it has been reported that the most frequent mutations in TRK are located at the solvent-front and near the DFG motif (G595R and G667C, respectively, for TRKA; G623R and G696A, respectively, for TRKC).(46,47) Molecular modeling suggests that mutation of Gly595 to arginine (G595R) at the solvent-front introduces steric hindrance with the hydroxypyrrolidine group of larotrectinib (Figure 4). Similarly, the glycine to cysteine G667C mutation close to the DFG motif increases steric hindrance with the difluorophenyl group of larotrectinib.
    To overcome the aforementioned TRK resistance mutations, two macrocyclic compounds LOXO-195 (6, Figure 4) and TPX-0005 (7, Figure 4) were developed to introduce increased conformation rigidity compared to the larotrectinib scaffold and avoid steric clashes with Arg595 and Cys667.(47,48) Molecular modeling indicated that LOXO-195 and TPX-0005 can occupy the ATP-binding site of mutated TRK without any steric impediments (Figure 4). LOXO-195 (selitrectinib) demonstrated low nanomolar inhibitory activity against TRK WT, G595R, and G667C mutants (IC50 = 0.6–9.8 nM) and significant in vitro and in vivo efficacy in a range of cancer models dependent on wild type and mutant variants of TRKA. TPX-0005 (repotrectinib) can effectively inhibit the activity of ROS1 and ALK solvent-front and near-DFG mutants in addition to TRK and its mutant forms in vitro and in vivo. Both agents are under clinical evaluation as second generation TRK inhibitors for patients with advanced TRK fusion-positive cancers.(47,48)

    2.2. Making Interactions with the Mutated Residue

    As described above, the second-generation ALK inhibitor ceritinib developed by Novartis was approved in 2014 for the treatment of ALK-positive NSCLC patients following progression on crizotinib.(49,50) Many of these patients present with acquired resistance due to the gatekeeper ALK L1196M mutation. Ceritinib was discovered following optimization of a 2,4-diaminopyrimidine-based high-throughput screening (HTS) hit with the purpose of improving the kinome selectivity and ADME properties of the class.(51) It demonstrates potent biochemical inhibition of ALK and excellent antiproliferative activity against NSCLC cells harboring EML4-ALK L1196M and G1269A mutants (Figure 5).(51,9) Of note, profiling of 280 kinases showed that ceritinib inhibits 16 kinases with a Ssel value of 2.6, indicating its selectivity is slightly better than that of crizotinib (Ssel = 2.7).(52) The cocrystal structure of ceritinib and ALK L1196M offers an explanation for the ability of ceritinib to maintain activity against this gatekeeper mutant. The chlorine substituent of the central aminopyrimidine ring of ceritinib is directed toward the small back pocket of the ATP-binding domain forming a hydrophobic interaction with Met1196 (Figure 5). This differs significantly from crizotinib where the methyl group adjacent to the alkoxy linker suffers from steric interference with the Met1196 side chain. In contrast with lorlatinib, ceritinib is inactive against the solvent-front G1202R crizotinib-resistance mutation as it also experiences steric hindrance between the bulky and rigid tetrasubstituted phenyl group and Arg1202.(9)
    Ariad Pharmaceuticals has reported a third-generation ALK inhibitor, brigatinib (9, Figure 5), a phosphine oxide-containing 2,4-diarylaminopyrimidine compound that exhibits greater potency than ceritinib against a broader range of acquired ALK mutants.(53,54) Brigatinib is highly active against the ALK L1196M gatekeeper mutation with a biochemical IC50 value of 1.7 nM. Further to this, it demonstrates potent antiproliferative activity against Ba/F3 cells harboring EML4-ALK L1196M with an IC50 value of 41 nM. The chlorine substituent at the pyrimidine ring C5-position is predicted to form a hydrophobic interaction with Met1196 in a similar manner to that of ceritinib (Figure 5). Unlike ceritinib, brigatinib maintains substantial activity against the ALK G1202R mutant with a biochemical IC5O value of 4.9 nM, although its antiproliferative potency in Ba/F3 EML4-ALK G1202R cells is less favorable (IC50 = 184 nM).(53) A comparison of the ceritinib and brigatinib ALK cocrystal structures suggests that the rotational flexibility of the brigatinib piperidinyl-piperazine hydrophilic moiety greatly reduces a steric clash with Arg1202, unlike the substituted phenyl group of ceritinib. The unique dimethylphosphine oxide and methoxy groups of brigatinib largely contribute to its improved potency and selectivity. In spite of this, its selectivity (Ssel = 3.3) is still worse than crizotinib (Ssel = 2.7) in 280 kinases profiling assay.(52) Brigatinib shows remarkable in vivo efficacy in mice against multiple NSCLC models driven by ALK wild type (WT) and mutant variants. It further demonstrates good CNS penetration. In 2017, brigatinib received accelerated approval from the FDA as a third-generation ALK inhibitor for the treatment of patients with ALK-positive metastatic NSCLC who are resistant or intolerant to crizotinib.(55)

    2.3. Forming a Covalent Bond with an Active Site Cysteine

    Activating mutations in the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) kinase domain (exon-21 L858R point mutation and exon-19 deletions) have been identified as oncogenic drivers for NSCLC.(56,57) The first-generation small molecule EGFR inhibitors, gefitinib (10, Figure 6) and erlotinib, were approved by the FDA in 2003 and 2004 (Figure 1), respectively, and have achieved significant clinical benefit for NSCLC patients with EGFR activating mutations.(58,59) Unfortunately, the vast majority of patients progress after 9–14 months of treatment due to acquired point mutations in the EGFR kinase domain or up-regulation of bypass signaling pathways. Of note, the EGFR T790M gatekeeper mutation is one of the primary mechanisms of resistance identified in 55–70% of mutant EGFR NSCLC patients progressing on first-generation EGFR inhibitors.(60) EGFR T790M mutation causes some loss of affinity of the inhibitors for the ATP-binding domain; however the dominant paradigm is an increase in affinity of ATP for the EGFR T790M active site (relative to the activating mutations) such that the first-generation reversible SMKIs are unable to compete with ATP efficiently at physiologically achievable concentrations.(61) To overcome acquired resistance caused by the EGFR T790M mutation, second-generation irreversible EGFR inhibitors such as canertinib, pelitinib, neratinib, afatinib (11, Figure 6), and dacomitinib were developed.(62) These irreversible inhibitors contain a Michael acceptor group positioned to form a covalent bond with a cysteine (Cys797) at the solvent-front of the EGFR ATP-binding domain. This approach was anticipated to be less sensitive to ATP affinity and achieve greater ligand occupancy and suppression of kinase signaling than the first-generation reversible inhibitors (Figure 6). The second-generation inhibitors afatinib and dacomitinib were approved by the FDA in 2013 and 2018, respectively, for the treatment of NSCLC patients with EGFR activating mutations. The latter agent demonstrated superiority over gefitinib in this setting following a randomized phase III trial (ARCHER 1050).(63)
    The Cys797-chelating second-generation irreversible inhibitors displayed promising efficacy in overcoming the EGFR T790M gatekeeper mutation in preclinical models. However, it is now widely accepted that this activity can only be achieved at supraphysiological concentrations that are not possible in patients due to dose-limiting toxicities (DLTs) derived from potent inhibition of wild type EGFR in skin and gastrointestinal tissues.(64,65) Indeed, recent reports indicate that EGFR T790M mutation is the major mechanism of acquired resistance to afatinib in NSCLC patients with EGFR activating mutations.(66) To avoid “on-target” toxicity, third-generation EGFR inhibitors have been developed that irreversibly inhibit mutant forms of EGFR including the EGFR T790M variant while sparing wild type EGFR. The 4-aminopyrimidine WZ4002 (12, Figure 6) was the first example reported, demonstrating good efficacy against EGFR L858R/T790M and EGFR Del19/T790M NSCLC models while being less potent against EGFR WT in vitro and in vivo.(67) A crystal structure of WZ4002 bound to EGFR T790M indicates its T790M mutant-selectivity derives from its “U-shaped” binding conformation, lack of occupancy of the hydrophobic back-pocket, and a lipophilic interaction between the pyrimidine ring chorine substituent and the gatekeeper Met790 residue (Figure 6). Unfortunately, WZ4002 failed to enter clinical development due to legal issues around the commercialization of the compound.
    In 2015, osimertinib (13, Figure 6), with a similar aminopyrimidine scaffold to WZ4002, gained accelerated approved by the FDA for the treatment of NSCLC patients progressing on a first-generation EGFR inhibitor whose disease is positive for the EGFR T790M mutation. In 2018, osimertinib gained FDA approval as a first-line treatment for metastatic NSCLC patients harboring EGFR activating mutations.(68) Osimertinib displayed low nanomolar potency against PC9 NSCLC cells harboring the EGFR Del19 mutation (IC50 = 17 nM) and H1975 NSCLC cells harboring the EGFR L858R/T790M mutation (IC50 = 15 nM) while sparing LoVo cells expressing EGFR WT (IC50 = 480 nM).(68,69) Modeling studies suggested osimertinib also bound EGFR T790M in a “U-shaped” conformation with the acrylamide forming a covalent bond with Cys797 and the aminopyrimidine core forming two conserved hydrogen bonds with Met793 (Figure 6). The N-methylindole of osimertinib forms hydrophobic interactions with the gatekeeper Met790 residue, which may help explain the selectivity of osimertinib for EGFR L858R/T790M over EGFR WT. Additionally, chemical proteomics studies indicated that osimertinib achieves good selectivity within the kinome.(70)

    2.4. Overriding Resistance to Irreversible Inhibitors with Reversible Inhibitors

    2.4.1. BTK C481S

    Bruton’s tyrosine kinase (BTK), a cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase in the Tec family, is a critical effector molecule for B-cell development that has been identified as a validated target for B-cell lymphoproliferative disorders,(71,72) such as hematologic malignancies and chronic inflammatory diseases.(73) More than a decade of research and development has seen several BTK inhibitors advance to clinical evaluation.(74,75) Ibrutinib (14, Figure 7) is notable as a first-in-class example that was approved in 2013 by the FDA for the treatment of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and mantle cell lymphoma (MCL).(76,77) Similar to the irreversible EGFR inhibitors that target EGFR Cys797, ibrutinib covalently binds the analogous Cys481 in the kinase domain of BTK.(78) Despite the remarkable efficacy of ibrutinib in the clinic, acquired resistance inevitably occurs, with the major cause of resistance having been identified as mutation of Cys481 to serine (C481S) resulting in disruption of inhibitor covalent binding.(79,80) Overcoming this resistance remains an unmet clinical need; however reversible ATP-competitive BTK inhibitors display promising potential to address acquired ibrutinib BTK C481S resistance.
    Currently available reversible BTK inhibitors, such as vecabrutinib, ARQ 531, and GDC-0583, do not rely upon covalent binding with Cys481 of BTK for inhibitory potency and therefore effectively retain potency against the acquired BTK C481S resistance mutation.(81) Vecabrutinib (15, Figure 7), developed by Sunesis Pharmaceuticals, is a reversible inhibitor of BTK WT and the BTK C481S mutant with biochemical IC50 values of 2.9 and 4.5 nM, respectively. Unlike ibrutinib, vecabrutinib has a good selectivity profile against the human kinome with off-target activity against only six other kinases including two Tec family members (ITK and TEC) and four non-Tec kinases. Of particular note, vecabrutinib does not inhibit EGFR, a common off-target hit for many BTK inhibitors. Vecabrutinib demonstrates favorable pharmacokinetic and toxicology profiles supporting sustained inhibition of BTK in vivo. It is currently under phase 1b/2 clinical investigation in patients with advanced B-cell malignancies, including those with a BTK C481S mutation (NCT03037645). ARQ 531 (16, Figure 7), with a similar structural skeleton to ibrutinib, is an orally bioavailable ATP-competitive reversible inhibitor of BTK.(82) ARQ 531 exhibits biochemical inhibition of BTK and BTK C481S with IC50 values of 0.85 and 0.39 nM. However, in addition to inhibiting BTK, ARQ 531 also inhibits Src, TEK, and the TRK family of kinases. Preclinical studies demonstrate that ARQ 531 significantly inhibits CLL cell survival and suppresses BCR-mediated activation of the BTK C481S and PLCγ2 mutations. It is currently in phase 1/2 clinical trial for the treatment of patients with relapsed or refractory hematologic malignancies (NCT03162536). A crystal structure of ARQ 531 bound to BTK demonstrates that it occupies the ATP-binding site of BTK without interacting with Cys481 (Figure 7), which suggests that the BTK C481S mutation will not affect its binding. Similar to ibrutinib, the pyrrolopyrimidine scaffold of ARQ 531 forms hydrogen bonds with Glu475 and Met477 in the hinge region of BTK, while the phenoxyphenyl group occupies the back pocket of the ATP-binding site. Notably, the tetrahydropyranyl methanol group forms a hydrogen bond network with Asn484 mediated by one water molecule, which directs it toward solvent accessible space.(82) GDC-0583 (17, Figure 7), an aminopyridone-based compound developed by Genentech, is an orally bioavailable and highly selective reversible BTK inhibitor that binds to the ATP-binding site of BTK without interacting with Cys481.(83) Preclinical studies suggested GDC-0853 possesses a favorable pharmacokinetic (PK) and pharmacodynamic (PD) profile and effectively suppresses B-cell and myeloid cell-mediated disease models in vitro and in vivo.(84) Currently, GDC-0853 (fenebrutinib) is under phase 1 clinical investigation in patients with relapsed or refractory B-cell non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma or chronic lymphocytic leukemia, including patients with a BTK C481S mutation (NCT01991184). GDC-0853 is in phase 2 clinical trial for patients with rheumatoid arthritis (NCT02833350). In addition, it has been suggested that GDC-0853 may have potential to overcome acquired resistance to ibrutinib caused by common BTK gatekeeper mutations (e.g., T474I and T474M) because its binding mode does not generate any steric hindrance with the gatekeeper residue.(85)

    2.4.2. EGFR C797S

    The Cys797-chelating third-generation irreversible EGFR inhibitors effectively overcome the gatekeeper T790M mutation and demonstrate great clinical benefit. Unfortunately, acquired resistance ultimately emerges in NSCLC patients through a tertiary Cys797 to serine (C797S) point mutation that disturbs covalent binding between the irreversible inhibitor and EGFR.(86,87) Indeed, the C797S mutation has become a leading mechanism of clinically acquired resistance in about 40% of patients treated with osimertinib.(88) Similar to the strategy outlined for BTK C481S mutation, selective ATP-competitive reversible EGFR inhibitors (defined as fourth-generation EGFR inhibitors) display promising potential to overcome acquired C797S resistance.(89) However, most current candidates are in the early preclinical phase and either lack selectivity over wild-type EGFR or lack in vivo potency. Recently, Boehringer Ingelheim reported a rigid macrocyclic compound, BI-4020 (20, Figure 8), based on the lead compound 19 (Figure 8), employing a restricted conformation strategy similar to that described above for LOXO-195 and TPX-0005 (Figure 4).(90) Although it is reported that the lead compound 19 was identified from an HTS approach, based on structural similarities, it could be argued that conceptually it represents a reversible analog of the third-generation EGFR inhibitor nazartinib (18, Figure 8). Biochemical and cellular assays demonstrate that BI-4020 effectively inhibits the EGFR T790M and C797S mutations and shows good efficacy in an osimertinib-resistant PC9 NSCLC xenograft model harboring the EGFR Del19/T790M/C797S triple mutant. Most recently, Eck et al. revealed that the noncovalent inhibitors of EGFR L858R/T790M/C797S, such as trisubstituted imidazoles or 19, overcome the C797S mutation through stabilization of the inactive kinase state anchored by forming a direct hydrogen bond with Lys745.(91) BI-4020 restricted its conformational space to the “active conformation” by means of macrocyclization, thus obtaining strong potency against EGFR L858R/T790M/C797S. Although BI-4020 has not entered clinical studies, its discovery demonstrates that reversible binding inhibitors may serve as a potential strategy to overcome EGFR C797S resistance mutations.
    To overcome acquired resistance to osimertinib, our group has reported a series of 5-methylpyrimidopyridone derivatives as selective reversible EGFR L858R/T790M/C797S inhibitors based on the irreversible EGFR L858R/T790M inhibitor 22 (Figure 9).(92) The representative compound 23 exhibited a biochemical IC50 of 27.5 nM against the EGFR L858R/T790M/C797S mutant while sparing EGFR WT with an IC50 value of greater than 1.0 μM. The X-ray crystal structure of 23 and EGFR T790M/C797S demonstrated that it binds reversibly at the ATP-binding site of EGFR with a U-shaped configuration. Notably, the 5-methyl substituent of 23 is directed toward Met790 forming a hydrophobic interaction, contributing greatly to the EGFR T790M/C797S selectivity (over EGFR WT).

    3. Alternative Approaches

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    3.1. Override ATP-Binding Site Mutations with Allosteric Inhibitors

    Allosteric kinase inhibitors, such as type III and type IV, are defined as inhibitors that bind to an allosteric site outside the conserved ATP-binding pocket that demonstrate no direct interaction with the hinge region of a kinase. In addition to the aforementioned specifically designed ATP-competitive inhibitors, allosteric kinase inhibitors have also become an effective strategy to overcome acquired resistance of traditional ATP-competitive inhibitors.(93,94) Two examples of clinically important targets with well-researched allosteric inhibitors, Bcr-Abl and EGFR, are discussed in this review. The development of allosteric inhibitors (type IV) that bind to the myristoyl pocket of Abl kinase in the C-terminal domain represents a promising strategy to overcome clinically acquired resistance to imatinib caused by mutations in the ATP-binding site. ABL001 (26, Figure 10), a potent and specific allosteric Abl kinase inhibitor discovered through hit-to-lead optimization of the GNF-2 and GNF-5 series (24 and 25, respectively, Figure 10),(95) mimics the myristate substrate, binding to Abl kinase with a Kd value of 0.5–0.8 nM.(96,97) ABL001 exhibits low nanomolar inhibition of all catalytic ATP-binding site mutations in Bcr-Abl including the gatekeeper T315I mutation. Notably, combination of ABL001 with ATP-competitive Abl inhibitors (such as nilotinib and ponatinib) not only effectively suppresses the emergence of resistance caused by secondary mutations in the ATP-binding site but also overcomes resistance observed to ABL001 caused by mutations within or near the allosteric myristoyl-binding pocket.(98,99) ABL001 (asciminib) is currently in clinical trials for the treatment of CML and Philadelphia chromosome-positive (Ph+) acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) as a single-agent and in combination with imatinib (NCT03106779 and NCT03578367, respectively).
    Similar to the strategy described for Bcr-Abl, the development of allosteric inhibitors that bind to a site adjacent to the ATP-binding pocket of EGFR, known as the MEK1/2 type III inhibitor (MT3) site (Figure 11), represents another potential solution to overcome acquired resistance to osimertinib caused by the EGFR T790M/C797S mutation. Two representative compounds, JBJ-04-125-02 (27)(100,101) and dibenzodiazepinone 28,(102) discovered as allosteric EGFR inhibitors following HTS approaches, exhibit subnanomolar to single-digit nanomolar potency against the EGFR L858R/T790M and EGFR L858R/T790M/C797S mutants in biochemical assays. Notably, JBJ-04-125-02 potently inhibits cell proliferation and EGFR L858R/T790M/C797S signaling in vitro and in vivo as a single agent. In addition, combination of osimertinib and JBJ-04-125-02 provides a significant increase in efficacy when compared with either single-agent treatment.(101) However, JBJ-04-125-02 is not active against EGFR Del19/T790M/C797S mutants. Dibenzodiazepinone 28 exhibits high selectivity in kinome profiling assays but weak cellular activity that can be improved through combination with the EGFR-targeted antibody cetuximab. Further optimization of this class is required to produce an allosteric inhibitor with improved single-agent cellular activity and ideal physicochemical properties. Nevertheless, these studies demonstrate that allosteric inhibitors of EGFR represent a promising potential strategy to combat clinically acquired osimertinib EGFR resistance mutations.

    3.2. Induced Degradation of Mutant Kinase Variants

    Unlike traditional small molecule inhibitors, PROTACs function by directly degrading a target protein of interest (POI) via the ubiquitin-proteasome system (Figure 12). PROTACs featured a bifunctional small molecule that can bind a POI and then recruit an E3-ligase. PROTAC-induced degradation is iterative and therefore less susceptible to increases in target expression or mutations than traditional small molecules, providing a new strategy to overcome acquired resistance due to on-target mutations.(103,104) Among the reported kinase PROTACs, only BTK degraders demonstrate high efficiency for drug-resistant mutant targets. The representative BTK degrader, L181 (29, Figure 12), reported in 2018,(105,106) comprising an ibrutinib BTK-binding scaffold and a lenalidomide E3-ligase recruiting ligand connected by a polyethylene glycol (PEG) linker, efficiently degrades wild type and clinically relevant BTK mutants (C481S/T/G/W/A) with DC50 values ranging from 18 to 41 nM. L181 potently inhibits the proliferation of ibrutinib-resistant diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) and mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) cells expressing the BTK C481S mutant. More importantly, L181 with a favorable toxicity profile and improved solubility over earlier examples showed potent in vivo antitumor efficacy in mice bearing HBL-1 xenografts that express the BTK C481S mutant. In the same year, a BTK degrader closely related in structure to L181, termed MT-802 (30, Figure 12),(107) was reported by Craig Crews’ laboratory to effectively degrade wild type and C481S mutant BTK with DC50 values of 14.6 and 14.9 nM, respectively. Moreover, MT-802 effectively inhibited the phosphorylated form of the BTK C481S mutant in primary cells derived from CLL patients. However, MT-802 has not undergone in-depth in vivo studies due to poor pharmacokinetic properties. Structurally more distinct than the aforementioned BTK degraders, Nathanael Gray’s group has reported DD-03-171 (31, Figure 12) as a potential BTK PROTAC.(108) The design of DD-03-171 is based on the reversible BTK inhibitor CGI1746 linked to the E3-ligase ligand, thalidomide, through a hydrocarbon chain.(109) DD-03-171 efficiently induced BTK C481S degradation and inhibited the proliferation of MCL cells with an IC50 value of 5.1 nM. Further, DD-03-171 effectively reduced tumor burden and extended survival in mice bearing PDX models of lymphoma. Outside the field of BTK, a Bcr-Abl PROTAC known as SIAIS178 has also been reported to degrade some clinically relevant mutants, such as the Bcr-Abl G250E/V299L/F317L(V) mutants. This agent however could not induce degradation of the common Bcr-Abl T315I gatekeeper mutation.(110) Nevertheless, the use of PROTACs to catalyze degradation of clinically acquired kinase mutant-variants may indeed provide an effective approach to overcome drug resistance caused by on-target point mutations.(111,112)

    4. Conclusions and Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Clinically acquired resistance to SMKIs represents a major challenge for current targeted cancer therapy. This has prompted medicinal chemists to design new generations of SMKI to override this resistance. On the basis of an understanding of the mechanism of acquired resistance induced by on-target mutations in the kinase domain, like common gatekeeper mutations, covalent binding site mutations, and solvent-front mutations, there are six SMKIs that have seen FDA approval with many other examples currently under clinical evaluation. The major medicinal chemistry approaches employed for the discovery of these representative SMKIs focused largely on optimization of existing drug scaffolds. Strategies include avoiding steric hindrance with the mutated residue, making interactions with the mutated residue, and forming a covalent bond with an active site cysteine to override resistance observed for reversible inhibitors. Briefly, ponatinib and lorlatinib, designed based on the respective first-generation inhibitors imatinib and crizotinib, avoid steric hindrance with gatekeeper mutations in Bcr-Abl and ALK. Ceritinib and brigatinib are designed to form hydrophobic interactions specifically with the ALK Met1196 gatekeeper mutation to overcome resistance to crizotinib. Osimertinib is designed to form a covalent bond with EGFR Cys797 to overcome acquired resistance to gefitinib and erlotinib caused by the EGFR T790M gatekeeper mutation. The BTK inhibitors vecabrutinib, ARQ 531, and GDC-0583 and the representative EGFR inhibitor BI-4020 are reversible inhibitors designed to overcome ibrutinib and osimertinib acquired resistance, respectively, induced through a cysteine to serine mutation. Although these latter inhibitors are still in clinical studies, they provide a very promising and powerful approach to overcome active site cysteine mutation.
    Despite tremendous progress, some opportunities and challenges remain to be addressed. First, with the increasing number of approved SMKIs, many other kinase point mutations have been identified as common causes of clinically acquired drug resistance. For many of these, such as FLT3 F691L/I and C-Kit T670I,(113,114) there are no effective drugs reported to be in clinical trial. The medicinal chemistry strategies described herein may warrant consideration for their potential to be extended to these mutant kinases enabling the discovery of new generations of inhibitor. Second, each generation of kinase inhibitor inevitably demonstrates acquired resistance induced by point mutations, and these mutations are usually centralized around the ATP-binding pocket. Therefore, it is suggested that the use of an allosteric kinase inhibitor in combination with an ATP-binding site inhibitor (of the same kinase) or the use of a PROTAC strategy may effectively overcome or reduce acquired resistance due to on-target mutations. However, on-target mutation is not the only mechanism of clinically acquired SMKI resistance. Other mechanisms include the activation of alternative signaling pathways (bypass signaling), phenotypic alterations, and target amplification or overexpression. Combination of SMKIs with other kinase inhibitors and conventional chemotherapeutic agents is also a promising strategy for combating drug resistance. Nevertheless, the strategies reviewed herein provide a solid foundation for the discovery of new generations of kinase inhibitor to overcome resistance caused by on-target mutations.

    1. 1
      Manning, G.; Whyte, D. B.; Martinez, R.; Hunter, T.; Sudarsanam, S. The Protein Kinase Complement of the Human Genome. Science 2002, 298 (5600), 1912– 1934,  DOI: 10.1126/science.1075762
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      The Protein Kinase Complement of the Human Genome
      Manning, G.; Whyte, D. B.; Martinez, R.; Hunter, T.; Sudarsanam, S.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2002), 298 (5600), 1912-1916, 1933-1934CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      We have catalogued the protein kinase complement of the human genome (the "kinome") using public and proprietary genomic, complementary DNA, and expressed sequence tag (EST) sequences. This provides a starting point for comprehensive anal. of protein phosphorylation in normal and disease states, as well as a detailed view of the current state of human genome anal. through a focus on one large gene family. We identify 518 putative protein kinase genes, of which 71 have not previously been reported or described as kinases, and we extend or correct the protein sequences of 56 more kinases. New genes include members of well-studied families as well as previously unidentified families, some of which are conserved in model organisms. Classification and comparison with model organism kinomes identified orthologous groups and highlighted expansions specific to human and other lineages. We also identified 106 protein kinase pseudogenes. Chromosomal mapping revealed several small clusters of kinase genes and revealed that 244 kinases map to disease loci or cancer amplicons.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xpt1Wisb0%253D&md5=b3def83bace52257a3252a3347b8bb92

      Wang, Z.; Cole, P. A. Catalytic Mechanisms and Regulation of Protein Kinases. Methods Enzymol. 2014, 548, 1– 21,  DOI: 10.1016/B978-0-12-397918-6.00001-X
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Catalytic mechanisms and regulation of protein kinases
      Wang, Zhihong; Cole, Philip A.
      Methods in Enzymology (2014), 548 (Protein Kinase Inhibitors in Research and Medicine), 1-21CODEN: MENZAU; ISSN:0076-6879. (Elsevier Inc.)
      A review. Protein kinases transfer a phosphoryl group from ATP onto target proteins and play a crit. role in signal transduction and other cellular processes. Here, we review the kinase kinetic and chem. mechanisms and their application in understanding kinase structure and function. Aberrant kinase activity has been implicated in many human diseases, in particular cancer. We highlight applications of technologies and concepts derived from kinase mechanistic studies that have helped illuminate how kinases are regulated and contribute to pathophysiol.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xht1Onu7nJ&md5=1f9dfeabf33b69658eb0eadaad6606c3

      Wu, P.; Nielsen, T. E.; Clausen, M. H. Small Molecule Kinase Inhibitors: an Analysis of FDA-Approved Drugs. Drug Discovery Today 2016, 21 (1), 5– 10,  DOI: 10.1016/j.drudis.2015.07.008
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Small-molecule kinase inhibitors: an analysis of FDA-approved drugs
      Wu, Peng; Nielsen, Thomas E.; Clausen, Mads H.
      Drug Discovery Today (2016), 21 (1), 5-10CODEN: DDTOFS; ISSN:1359-6446. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Small-mol. kinase inhibitors (SMKIs), 28 of which are approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), have been actively pursued as promising targeted therapeutics. Here, we assess the key structural and physicochem. properties, target selectivity and mechanism of function, and therapeutic indications of these approved inhibitors. Our anal. showed that >30% of approved SMKIs have a mol. wt. (MW) exceeding 500 and all have a total ring count of between three and five. The assumption that type II inhibitors tend to be more selective than type I inhibitors has been proved to be unreliable. Although previous SMKI research was concd. on tyrosine kinase inhibitors for cancer treatment, recent progress indicates diversification of SMKI research in terms of new targets, mechanistic types, and therapeutic indications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXht1Gru73P&md5=228524fa464393053ecbfac19e994929

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      FDA-approved small-molecule kinase inhibitors
      Wu, Peng; Nielsen, Thomas E.; Clausen, Mads H.
      Trends in Pharmacological Sciences (2015), 36 (7), 422-439CODEN: TPHSDY; ISSN:0165-6147. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A review. Kinases have emerged as one of the most intensively pursued targets in current pharmacol. research, esp. for cancer, due to their crit. roles in cellular signaling. To date, the US FDA has approved 28 small-mol. kinase inhibitors, half of which were approved in the past 3 years. While the clin. data of these approved mols. are widely presented and structure-activity relationship (SAR) has been reported for individual mols., an updated review that analyzes all approved mols. and summarizes current achievements and trends in the field has yet to be found. Here we present all approved small-mol. kinase inhibitors with an emphasis on binding mechanism and structural features, summarize current challenges, and discuss future directions in this field.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXns1KisLg%253D&md5=a6aa3dbb11e6fe3001fa5fa03a4c950a

      Davies, S. P.; Reddy, H.; Caivano, M.; Cohen, P. Specificity and Mechanism of Action of Some Commonly Used Protein Kinase Inhibitors. Biochem. J. 2000, 351 (1), 95– 105,  DOI: 10.1042/bj3510095
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      Specificity and mechanism of action of some commonly used protein kinase inhibitors
      Davies, Stephen P.; Reddy, Helen; Caivano, Matilde; Cohen, Philip
      Biochemical Journal (2000), 351 (1), 95-105CODEN: BIJOAK; ISSN:0264-6021. (Portland Press Ltd.)
      The specificities of 28 com. available compds. reported to be relatively selective inhibitors of particular serine/threonine-specific protein kinases have been examd. against a large panel of protein kinases. The compds. KT 5720, Rottlerin and quercetin were found to inhibit many protein kinases, sometimes much more potently than their presumed targets, and conclusions drawn from their use in cell-based expts. are likely to be erroneous. Ro 318220 and related bisindoylmaleimides, as well as H89, HA1077 and Y 27632, were more selective inhibitors, but still inhibited two or more protein kinases with similar potency. LY 294002 was found to inhibit casein kinase-2 with similar potency to phosphoinositide (phosphatidylinositol) 3-kinase. The compds. with the most impressive selectivity profiles were KN62, PD 98059, U0126, PD 184352, rapamycin, wortmannin, SB 203580 and SB 202190. U0126 and PD 184352, like PD 98059, were found to block the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) cascade in cell-based assays by preventing the activation of MAPK kinase (MKK1), and not by inhibiting MKK1 activity directly. Apart from rapamycin and PD 184352, even the most selective inhibitors affected at least one addnl. protein kinase. Our results demonstrate that the specificities of protein kinase inhibitors cannot be assessed simply by studying their effect on kinases that are closely related in primary structure. The authors propose guidelines for the use of protein kinase inhibitors in cell-based assays.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXnslWltrY%253D&md5=e14eb47a52dc43afca7373c276b2d147

      Rotow, J.; Bivona, T. G. Understanding and Targeting Resistance Mechanisms in NSCLC. Nat. Rev. Cancer 2017, 17 (11), 637– 658,  DOI: 10.1038/nrc.2017.84
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Understanding and targeting resistance mechanisms in NSCLC
      Rotow, Julia; Bivona, Trever G.
      Nature Reviews Cancer (2017), 17 (11), 637-658CODEN: NRCAC4; ISSN:1474-175X. (Nature Research)
      A review. In this Review, we discuss alterations in the targeted oncogene ('on-target' resistance) and in other downstream and parallel pathways ('off-target' resistance) leading to resistance to targeted therapies in NSCLC, and we provide an overview of the current understanding of the bidirectional interactions with the tumor microenvironment that promote therapeutic resistance. We highlight common mechanistic themes underpinning resistance to targeted therapies that are shared by NSCLC subtypes, including those with oncogenic alterations in epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK), ROS1 proto-oncogene receptor tyrosine kinase (ROS1), serine/threonine-protein kinase b-raf (BRAF) and other less established oncoproteins. Finally, we discuss how understanding these themes can inform therapeutic strategies, including combination therapy approaches, and overcome the challenge of tumor heterogeneity.

      Lategahn, J.; Keul, M.; Rauh, D. Lessons To Be Learned: The Molecular Basis of Kinase-Targeted Therapies and Drug Resistance in Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2018, 57 (9), 2307– 2313,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201710398

      7
      Lessons to be Learned: The Molecular Basis of Kinase-Targeted Therapies and Drug Resistance in Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer
      Lategahn, Jonas; Keul, Marina; Rauh, Daniel
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2018), 57 (9), 2307-2313CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review. The treatment of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is currently experiencing a revolution. Over the last decade, the knowledge gained about the biochem. features of biomarkers and their predictive abilities has led to the development of targeted small-mol. inhibitors that present an alternative to harsh chemotherapy. The use of these new therapies has improved the quality of life and increased the survival of patients. The occurrence of inevitable drug resistance requires the const. development of precision medicine. The detailed understanding of the target biol. and the search for innovative chem. approaches has encouraged investigations in this field. Herein, the authors review selected aspects of the mol. targets and present an overview of current topics and challenges in the rational development of small mols. to target NSCLC.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXoslygtw%253D%253D&md5=78d3ce523d076c820cb7fcbf9a321e63
    8. 8
      O’Hare, T.; Shakespeare, W. C.; Zhu, X.; Eide, C. A.; Rivera, V. M.; Wang, F.; Adrian, L. T.; Zhou, T.; Huang, W.-S.; Xu, Q.; Metcalf, C. A.; Tyner, J. W.; Loriaux, M. M.; Corbin, A.       [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      AP24534, a pan-BCR-ABL inhibitor for chronic myeloid leukemia, potently inhibits the T315I mutant and overcomes mutation-based resistance
      O'Hare, Thomas; Shakespeare, William C.; Zhu, Xiaotian; Eide, Christopher A.; Rivera, Victor M.; Wang, Frank; Adrian, Lauren T.; Zhou, Tianjun; Huang, Wei-Sheng; Xu, Qihong; Metcalf, Chester A., III; Tyner, Jeffrey W.; Loriaux, Marc M.; Corbin, Amie S.; Wardwell, Scott; Ning, Yaoyu; Keats, Jeffrey A.; Wang, Yihan; Sundaramoorthi, Raji; Thomas, Mathew; Zhou, Dong; Snodgrass, Joseph; Commodore, Lois; Sawyer, Tomi K.; Dalgarno, David C.; Deininger, Michael W. N.; Druker, Brian J.; Clackson, Tim
      Cancer Cell (2009), 16 (5), 401-412CODEN: CCAECI; ISSN:1535-6108. (Cell Press)
      Inhibition of BCR-ABL by imatinib induces durable responses in many patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), but resistance attributable to kinase domain mutations can lead to relapse and a switch to second-line therapy with nilotinib or dasatinib. Despite three approved therapeutic options, the cross-resistant BCR-ABLT315I mutation and compd. mutants selected on sequential inhibitor therapy remain major clin. challenges. We report design and preclin. evaluation of AP24534, a potent, orally available multitargeted kinase inhibitor active against T315I and other BCR-ABL mutants. AP24534 inhibited all tested BCR-ABL mutants in cellular and biochem. assays, suppressed BCR-ABLT315I-driven tumor growth in mice, and completely abrogated resistance in cell-based mutagenesis screens. Our work supports clin. evaluation of AP24534 as a pan-BCR-ABL inhibitor for treatment of CML.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsFKltb3N&md5=62a383734fc345b97647ba71aa7aee04
    9. 9
      Friboulet, L.; Li, N.; Katayama, R.; Lee, C. C.; Gainor, J. F.; Crystal, A. S.; Michellys, P.-Y.; Awad, M. M.; Yanagitani, N.; Kim, S.; Pferdekamper, A. C.; Li, J.; Kasibhatla, S.; Sun, F.; Sun, X.; Hua, S.; McNamara, P.; Mahmood, S.; Lockerman, E. L.; Fujita, N.; Nishio, M.; Harris, J. L.; Shaw, A. T.; Engelman, J. A.       9
      The ALK Inhibitor Ceritinib Overcomes Crizotinib Resistance in Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer
      Friboulet, Luc; Li, Nanxin; Katayama, Ryohei; Lee, Christian C.; Gainor, Justin F.; Crystal, Adam S.; Michellys, Pierre-Yves; Awad, Mark M.; Yanagitani, Noriko; Kim, Sungjoon; Pferdekamper, AnneMarie C.; Li, Jie; Kasibhatla, Shailaja; Sun, Frank; Sun, Xiuying; Hua, Su; McNamara, Peter; Mahmood, Sidra; Lockerman, Elizabeth L.; Fujita, Naoya; Nishio, Makoto; Harris, Jennifer L.; Shaw, Alice T.; Engelman, Jeffrey A.
      Cancer Discovery (2014), 4 (6), 662-673CODEN: CDAIB2; ISSN:2159-8274. (American Association for Cancer Research)
      Non-small cell lung cancers (NSCLC) harboring anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) gene rearrangements invariably develop resistance to the ALK tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) crizotinib. Herein, we report the first preclin. evaluation of the next-generation ALK TKI, ceritinib (LDKB78), in the setting of crizotinib resistance. An interrogation of in vitro and in vivo models of acquired resistance to crizotinib, including cell lines established from biopsies of patients with crizotinib-resistant NSCLC, revealed that ceritinib potently overcomes crizotinib-resistant mutations. In particular, ceritinib effectively inhibits ALK harboring L1196M, G1269A, 11171T1 and S1206Y mutations, and a cocrystal structure of ceritinib bound to ALK provides structural bases for this increased potency. However, we obsd. that ceritinib did not overcome two crizotinib-resistant ALK mutations, G1202R and F1174C, and one of these mutations was identified in 5 of 11 biopsies from patients with acquired resistance to ceritinib. Altogether, our results demonstrate that ceritinib can overcome crizotinib resistance, consistent with clin. data showing marked efficacy of ceritinib in patients with crizotinib-resistant disease.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

    10. 10
      Zou, H. Y.; Li, Q.; Engstrom, L. D.; West, M.; Appleman, V.; Wong, K. A.; McTigue, M.; Deng, Y.-L.; Liu, W.; Brooun, A.; Timofeevski, S.; McDonnell, S. R. P.; Jiang, P.; Falk, M. D.; Lappin, P. B.; Affolter, T.; Nichols, T.; Hu, W.; Lam, J.; Johnson, T. W.; Smeal, T.; Charest, A.; Fantin, V. R. PF-06463922 is a Potent and Selective Next-Generation ROS1/ALK Inhibitor Capable of Blocking Crizotinib Resistant ROS1 Mutations. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2015, 112 (11), 3493– 3498,  DOI: 10.1073/pnas.1420785112
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      PF-06463922 is a potent and selective next-generation ROS1/ALK inhibitor capable of blocking crizotinib-resistant ROS1 mutations
      Zou, Helen Y.; Li, Qiuhua; Engstrom, Lars D.; West, Melissa; Appleman, Vicky; Wong, Katy A.; McTigue, Michele; Deng, Ya-Li; Liu, Wei; Brooun, Alexei; Timofeevski, Sergei; McDonnell, Scott R. P.; Jiang, Ping; Falk, Matthew D.; Lappin, Patrick B.; Affolter, Timothy; Nichols, Tim; Hu, Wenyue; Lam, Justine; Johnson, Ted W.; Smeal, Tod; Charest, Al; Fantin, Valeria R.
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2015), 112 (11), 3493-3498CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
      Oncogenic c-ros oncogene 1 (ROS1) fusion kinases have been identified in a variety of human cancers and are attractive targets for cancer therapy. The MET/ALK/ROS1 inhibitor crizotinib (Xalkori, PF-02341066) has demonstrated promising clin. activity in ROS1 fusion-pos. non-small cell lung cancer. However, emerging clin. evidence has shown that patients can develop resistance by acquiring secondary point mutations in ROS1 kinase. In this study the authors characterized the ROS1 activity of PF-06463922, a novel, orally available, CNS-penetrant, ATP-competitive small-mol. inhibitor of ALK/ROS1. In vitro, PF-06463922 exhibited subnanomolar cellular potency against oncogenic ROS1 fusions and inhibited the crizotinib-refractory ROS1G2032R mutation and the ROS1G2026M gatekeeper mutation. Compared with crizotinib and the second-generation ALK/ROS1 inhibitors ceritinib and alectinib, PF-06463922 showed significantly improved inhibitory activity against ROS1 kinase. A crystal structure of the PF-06463922-ROS1 kinase complex revealed favorable interactions contributing to the high-affinity binding. In vivo, PF-06463922 showed marked antitumor activity in tumor models expressing FIG-ROS1, CD74-ROS1, and the CD74-ROS1G2032R mutation. Furthermore, PF-06463922 demonstrated antitumor activity in a genetically engineered mouse model of FIG-ROS1 glioblastoma. Taken together, the authors' results indicate that PF-06463922 has potential for treating ROS1 fusion-pos. cancers, including those requiring agents with CNS-penetrating properties, as well as for overcoming crizotinib resistance driven by ROS1 mutation.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

AZD9291, an Irreversible EGFR TKI, Overcomes T790M-Mediated Resistance to EGFR Inhibitors in Lung Cancer. Cancer Discovery 2014, 4 (9), 1046– 1061,  DOI: 10.1158/2159-8290.CD-14-0337

      11
      AZD9291, an Irreversible EGFR TKI, Overcomes T790M-Mediated Resistance to EGFR Inhibitors in Lung Cancer
      Cross, Darren A. E.; Ashton, Susan E.; Ghiorghiu, Serban; Eberlein, Cath; Nebhan, Caroline A.; Spitzler, Paula J.; Orme, Jonathon P.; Finlay, M. Raymond V.; Ward, Richard A.; Mellor, Martine J.; Hughes, Gareth; Rahi, Amar; Jacobs, Vivien N.; Brewer, Monica Red; Ichihara, Eiki; Sun, Jing; Jin, Hailing; Ballard, Peter; Al-Kadhimi, Katherine; Rowlinson, Rachel; Klinowska, Teresa; Richmond, Graham H.       Cancer Discovery (2014), 4 (9), 1046-1061CODEN: CDAIB2; ISSN:2159-8274. (American Association for Cancer Research)
      A third-generation EGFR inhibitor selectively targets EGFR mutants, including T790M, but not wild-type EGFR, and induces durable antitumor responses in preclin. models and patients with NSCLC.

      Daley, G.; Van Etten, R.; Baltimore, D. Induction of Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia in Mice by the P210bcr/abl Gene of the Philadelphia Chromosome. Science 1990, 247 (4944), 824– 830,  DOI: 10.1126/science.2406902

      12
      Induction of chronic myelogenous leukemia in mice by the P210bcr/abl gene of the Phildelphia chromosome
      Daley, George Q.; Van Etten, Richard A.; Baltimore, David
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (1990), 247 (4944), 824-30CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075.
      In tumor cells from virtually all patients with chronic myelogenous leukemia, the Philadelphia chromosome, a fusion of chromosomes 9 and 22, directs the synthesis of the P210bcr/abl protein. The protein-tyrosine kinase activity and hybrid structure of P210bcr/abl are similar to the oncogene product of the Abelson murine leukemia virus, P160gag/v-abl, which induces acute lymphomas. To det. whether P210bcr/abl can induce chronic myelogenous leukemia, murine bone marrow was infected with a retrovirus encoding P210bcr/abl and transplanted into irradiated syngeneic recipients. Transplant recipients developed several hematol. malignancies; prominent among them was a myeloproliferative syndrome closely resembling the chronic phase of human chronic myelogenous leukemia. Tumor tissue from diseased mice harbored the provirus encoding P210bcr/abl. These results demonstrate that P210bcr/abl expression can induce chronic myelogenous leukemia. Retrovirus-mediated expression of the protein provides a murine model system for further anal. of the disease.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3cXhsFaqs7c%253D&md5=6f36223545c27d509c8ff075de8eb4ca
    13. 13
      Renshaw, M. W.; McWhirter, J. R.; Wang, J. Y. The Human Leukemia Oncogene bcr-abl Abrogates the Anchorage Requirement But Not the Growth Factor Requirement for Proliferation. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1995, 15 (3), 1286– 1293,  DOI: 10.1128/MCB.15.3.1286
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13
      The human leukemia oncogene bcr-abl abrogates the anchorage requirement but not the growth factor requirement for proliferation
      Renshaw, Mark W.; McWhirter, John R.; Wang, Jean Y. J.
      Molecular and Cellular Biology (1995), 15 (3), 1286-93CODEN: MCEBD4; ISSN:0270-7306. (American Society for Microbiology)
      Proliferation of normal cells in a multicellular organism requires not only growth factors but also the proper attachment to the extracellular matrix. A hallmark of neoplastic transformation is the loss of anchorage dependence which usually accompanies the loss of growth factor requirement. The Bcr-Abl tyrosine kinase of human leukemias is shown here to abrogate only the anchorage, not the growth factor, requirement. Bcr-Abl-transformed cells grow in soft agar but do not proliferate in serum-free media. Bcr-Abl does not activate the tetradecanoyl phorbol acetate response element (TRE). However, Bcr-Abl can alleviate the anchorage requirement for the induction of the TRE enhancer; i.e., it allows serum to activate the TRE in detached cells. This activity is dependent on the assocn. of an active Bcr-Abl tyrosine kinase with the actin filaments. Despite its assocn. with the adapter protein Grb2, Bcr-Abl's effect on the TRE enhancer is not blocked by dominant neg. Ras or Raf. The finding that Bcr-Abl tyrosine kinase abrogates only anchorage dependence may have important implications on the pathogenesis of chronic myelogenous leukemia.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXjsl2rtr4%253D&md5=eb67facca4fedf9e1204994636d208ae

      Schindler, T.; Bornmann, W.; Pellicena, P.; Miller, W. T.; Clarkson, B.; Kuriyan, J. Structural Mechanism for STI-571 Inhibition of Abelson Tyrosine Kinase. Science 2000, 289 (5486), 1938– 1942,  DOI: 10.1126/science.289.5486.1938
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      14
      Structural mechanism for STI-571 inhibition of Abelson tyrosine kinase
      Schindler, Thomas; Bornmann, William; Pellicena, Patricia; Miller, W. Todd; Clarkson, Bayard; Kuriyan, John
      Science (Washington, D. C.) (2000), 289 (5486), 1938-1942CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      The inadvertent activation of the Abelson tyrosine kinase (Abl) causes chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). A small-mol. inhibitor of Abl (STI-571) is effective in the treatment of CML. We report the crystal structure of the catalytic domain of Abl, complexed to a variant of STI-571. Crit. to the binding of STI-571 is the adoption by the kinase of an inactive conformation, in which a centrally located "activation loop" is not phosphorylated. The conformation of this loop is distinct from that in active protein kinases, as well as in the inactive form of the closely related Src kinases. These results suggest that compds. that exploit the distinctive inactivation mechanisms of individual protein kinases can achieve both high affinity and high specificity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXms1altLc%253D&md5=56bb233f010f099d0073020ac6b9db59
    15. 15
      Nagar, B.; Bornmann, W. G.; Pellicena, P.; Schindler, T.; Veach, D. R.; Miller, W. T.; Clarkson, B.; Kuriyan, J. Crystal Structures of the Kinase Domain of c-Abl in Complex with the Small Molecule Inhibitors PD173955 and Imatinib (STI-571). Cancer Res. 2002, 62 (15), 4236– 4243
      [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      15
      Crystal structures of the kinase domain of c-Abl in complex with the small molecule inhibitors PD173955 and imatinib (STI-571)
      Nagar, Bhushan; Bornmann, William G.; Pellicena, Patricia; Schindler, Thomas; Veach, Darren R.; Miller, W. Todd; Clarkson, Bayard; Kuriyan, John
      Cancer Research (2002), 62 (15), 4236-4243CODEN: CNREA8; ISSN:0008-5472. (American Association for Cancer Research)
      The inadvertent fusion of the bcr gene with the abl gene results in a constitutively active tyrosine kinase (Bcr-Abl) that transforms cells and causes chronic myelogenous leukemia. Small mol. inhibitors of Bcr-Abl that bind to the kinase domain can be used to treat chronic myelogenous leukemia. We report crystal structures of the kinase domain of Abl in complex with two such inhibitors, imatinib (also known as STI-571 and Gleevec) and PD173955 (Parke-Davis). Both compds. bind to the canonical ATP-binding site of the kinase domain, but they do so in different ways. As shown previously in a crystal structure of Abl bound to a smaller variant of STI-571, STI-571 captures a specific inactive conformation of the activation loop of Abl in which the loop mimics bound peptide substrate. In contrast, PD173955 binds to a conformation of Abl in which the activation loop resembles that of an active kinase. The structure suggests that PD173955 would be insensitive to whether the conformation of the activation loop corresponds to active kinases or to that seen in the STI-571 complex. In vitro kinase assays confirm that this is the case and indicate that PD173955 is at least 10-fold more inhibitory than STI-571. The structures suggest that PD173955 achieves its greater potency over STI-571 by being able to target multiple forms of Abl (active or inactive), whereas STI-571 requires a specific inactive conformation of Abl.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XlvFeltLY%253D&md5=843213cd6038ed82a0e43dce56e81a91
    16. 16
      O’Hare, T.; Eide, C. A.; Deininger, M. W. N. Bcr-Abl Kinase Domain Mutations, Drug Resistance, and the Road to a Ccure For Chronic Myeloid Leukemia. Blood 2007, 110 (7), 2242– 2249,  DOI: 10.1182/blood-2007-03-066936
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      16
      Bcr-Abl kinase domain mutations, drug resistance, and the road to a cure for chronic myeloid leukemia
      O'Hare, Thomas; Eide, Christopher A.; Deininger, Michael W. N.
      Blood (2007), 110 (7), 2242-2249CODEN: BLOOAW; ISSN:0006-4971. (American Society of Hematology)
      A review. Mutations in the kinase domain (KD) of BCR-ABL are the most prevalent mechanism of acquired imatinib resistance in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). Here we examine predisposing factors underlying acquisition of KD mutations, evidence for acquisition of mutations before and during therapy, and whether the detection of a KD mutation universally implies resistance. We also provide a perspective on how the secondline Abl inhibitors dasatinib and nilotinib are faring in the treatment of imatinib-resistant CML, esp. in relation to specific KD mutations. We discuss the growing importance of the multi-inhibitor-resistant 315T>I mutant and the therapeutic potential that a 315T>I inhibitor would have. Last, we assess the potential of Abl kinase inhibitor combinations to induce stable responses even in advanced CML and interpret the emerging data in the context of CML pathogenesis.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

    17. 17
      Shah, N. P.; Nicoll, J. M.; Nagar, B.; Gorre, M. E.; Paquette, R. L.; Kuriyan, J.; Sawyers, C. L. Multiple BCR-ABL Kinase Domain Mutations Confer Polyclonal Resistance to the Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitor Imatinib (STI571) in Chronic Phase and Blast Crisis Chronic Myeloid Leukemia. Cancer Cell 2002, 2 (2), 117– 125,  DOI: 10.1016/S1535-6108(02)00096-X
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      17
      Multiple BCR-ABL kinase domain mutations confer polyclonal resistance to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor imatinib (STI571) in chronic phase and blast crisis chronic myeloid leukemia
      Shah, Neil P.; Nicoll, John M.; Nagar, Bhushan; Gorre, Mercedes E.; Paquette, Ronald L.; Kuriyan, John; Sawyers, Charles L.
      Cancer Cell (2002), 2 (2), 117-125CODEN: CCAECI; ISSN:1535-6108. (Cell Press)
      Through sequencing anal. of blood or bone marrow samples from patients with chronic myeloid leukemia, we identified BCR-ABL kinase domain mutations in 29 of 32 patients whose disease relapsed after an initial response to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor imatinib. Fifteen different amino acid substitutions affecting 13 residues in the kinase domain were found. Mutations fell into two groups-those that alter amino acids that directly contact imatinib and those postulated to prevent BCR-ABL from achieving the inactive conformational state required for imatinib binding. Distinct mutations conferred varying degrees of imatinib resistance. Mutations detected in a subset of patients with stable chronic phase disease correlated with subsequent disease progression. Multiple independent mutant clones were detected in a subset of relapsed cases. Our data support a clonal selection model of preexisting BCR-ABL mutations that confer imatinib resistance.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XmslSks7c%253D&md5=2edcdc31ccc39ccc495e5eddeb4856e1

      Gorre, M. E.; Mohammed, M.; Ellwood, K.; Hsu, N.; Paquette, R.; Rao, P. N.; Sawyers, C. L. Clinical Resistance to STI-571 Cancer Therapy Caused by BCR-ABL Gene Mutation or Amplification. Science 2001, 293 (5531), 876– 880,  DOI: 10.1126/science.1062538
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      18
      Clinical resistance to STI-571 cancer therapy caused by BCR-ABL gene mutation or amplification
      Gorre, Mercedes E.; Mohammed, Mansoor; Ellwood, Katharine; Hsu, Nicholas; Paquette, Ron; Rao, P. Nagesh; Sawyers, Charles L.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2001), 293 (5531), 876-880CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Clin. studies with the Abl tyrosine kinase inhibitor STI-571 in chronic myeloid leukemia demonstrate that many patients with advanced stage disease respond initially but then relapse. Through biochem. and mol. anal. of clin. material, we find that drug resistance is assocd. with the reactivation of BCR-ABL signal transduction in all cases examd. In six of nine patients, resistance was assocd. with a single amino acid substitution in a threonine residue of the Abl kinase domain known to form a crit. hydrogen bond with the drug. This substitution of threonine with isoleucine was sufficient to confer STI-571 resistance in a reconstitution expt. In three patients, resistance was assocd. with progressive BCR-ABL gene amplification. These studies provide evidence that genetically complex cancers retain dependence on an initial oncogenic event and suggest STI-571 resistance.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Weisberg, E.; Manley, P. W.; Cowan-Jacob, S. W.; Hochhaus, A.; Griffin, J. D. Second Generation Inhibitors of BCR-ABL for the Treatment of Imatinib-Resistant Chronic Myeloid Leukaemia. Nat. Rev. Cancer 2007, 7 (5), 345– 356,  DOI: 10.1038/nrc2126

      Second generation inhibitors of BCR-ABL for the treatment of imatinib-resistant chronic myeloid leukemia
      Weisberg, Ellen; Manley, Paul W.; Cowan-Jacob, Sandra W.; Hochhaus, Andreas; Griffin, James D.
      Nature Reviews Cancer (2007), 7 (5), 345-356CODEN: NRCAC4; ISSN:1474-175X. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Imatinib, a small-mol. ABL kinase inhibitor, is a highly effective therapy for early-phase chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), which has constitutively active ABL kinase activity owing to the expression of the BCR-ABL fusion protein. However, there is a high relapse rate among advanced- and blast-crisis-phase patients owing to the development of mutations in the ABL kinase domain that cause drug resistance. Several second-generation ABL kinase inhibitors have been or are being developed for the treatment of imatinib-resistant CML. Here, we describe the mechanism of action of imatinib in CML, the structural basis of imatinib resistance, and the potential of second-generation BCR-ABL inhibitors to circumvent resistance.

      Corbin, A. S.; Buchdunger, E.; Pascal, F.; Druker, B. J. Analysis of the Structural Basis of Specificity of Inhibition of the Abl Kinase by STI571. J. Biol. Chem. 2002, 277 (35), 32214– 32219,  DOI: 10.1074/jbc.M111525200
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      20
      Analysis of the structural basis of specificity of inhibition of the Abl kinase by STI571
      Corbin, Amie S.; Buchdunger, Elisabeth; Pascal, Furet; Druker, Brian J.
      Journal of Biological Chemistry (2002), 277 (35), 32214-32219CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
      STI571, a selective inhibitor of Bcr-Abl, has been a successful therapeutic agent in clin. trials for chronic myelogenous leukemia. Chronic phase chronic myelogenous leukemia patients treated with STI571 have durable responses; however, most responding blast phase patients relapse despite continued therapy. Co-crystn. studies of Abl kinase and an STI571-related compd. identify specific amino acid residues as crit. to STI571 binding, one of which, T315, has been characterized as an acquired Thr to Ile mutation in relapsed patients. Other studies, however, suggest that mutations other than these predicted contact points are capable of conferring STI571 resistance in relapsed patients. Using a variety of models of STI571 binding to the Abl kinase, we have performed an extensive mutational anal. of sites that might alter the sensitivity of the Abl kinase to STI571. Although mutation of many of the predicted contact points between Abl and STI571 result in a kinase-inactive protein, addnl. mutations that render the Abl kinase less sensitive to STI571 demonstrate a broad range of possibilities for clin. resistance that are now becoming evident.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
